description.en: The course starts with on-site session where students learn how to formulate research problems and aims of development work and how to design a study. Next, quantitative and qualitative research approach will be introduced in the context of design-based research and action research. Data collection and analysis methods are introduced for using interviews, questionnaires, content analysis, experimental design, comparative analyses and correlations. Basics of literature search and critical analysis will be learned. Every topic will be practiced in a seminar or practicum. The course continues in e-learning where the topics will be elaborated using course materials, recommended literature and discussions in Moodle. Every student runs a small research or development project and analyses the collected data. The course finishes with evaluation of peers' projects. Project works will be presented and discussed in a webinar.

objectives.en: The course gives general overview about research and development work in educational technology, formulating research problems and aims for development work, and about research designs for solving these problems. In addition, different methods for evaluating quality of research and development work and educational technology solutions will be introduced.

independent_work.et:
1. Reading course materials in Moodle and participating in relevant asynchronous and synchronous discussions.
2. Two analytics tasks: choosing and applying learning analytics methods to analyze two learning activities, an individual and a collaborative activity. Reporting findings.
3. Giving feedback to peer students about their analytics tasks.
4. Evaluating analytics tasks of the peer students.

Guidelines are given in Moodle.

description.et:
The analytics tasks will be evaluated by peer students and teachers. The following criteria will be evaluated:
1) accordance with the learning context (10%),
2) quality of the analytical approach (35%),
3) technical quality of the analytics (application) (20%)
4) quality of the findings and reporting (35%),
The sum of average scores of teachers will be used for the final score. They will get a mark:
A - 91-100% of maximum score
B - 81-90% of maximum score
C - 71-80% of maximum score
D - 61-70% of maximum score
E - 51-60% of maximum score
F (failed) - 50% or of the maximum score or at least one of the criteria is assessed 50% or less from the maximum.

The students fill in an online test that consists of three parts each representing one of the learning outcomes of the course. Students are allowed to use all materials available in Internet but not the help of peer students.
They will get a mark:
A - 91-100% of correct answers
B - 81-90% of correct answers
C - 71-80% of correct answers
D - 61-70% of correct answers
E - 51-60% of correct answers
F (failed) - 50% or less correct answers or at least one of the expected learning outcomes is not achieved at the E level.

grade_preconditions.et:
The assignments have to be submitted during the course.
The analytics tasks, feedback to peer students and evaluations of peer students' analytics tasks have to be submitted before the examination.
The students have to participate in the online discussions about course materials.

grade_evaluation.et: Assessment is based on problem tasks (50%) and achievement test (50%). Both of them should be completed at least at E-level. The final score is based on the average of the scores in both assessment methods.

debt_elimination.et: According to the agreement with the teacher in charge, following the rules set in university's study regulations.
